subject: Re: RE: [junit] How can i test a geter or seter?
msgSnippet: David V. Olivier: That what i think about, may be the example is too simple to view what i think. (-: ¡¡¡¡ ======== 2001-12-21 12:53:00 You Write£º
messageBody:
David V. Olivier:

 That what i think about, may be the example is too simple to view what i think. (-:

　　
 
======== 2001-12-21 12:53:00 You Write： ========
 
An additional motivation:

While the get method, itself, may be quite simple the value of i could be
the result of complex behavior of the object.  Since the objects internal
state would only be visible via its get methods, we are not merely testing
the functionality of the get method but also the validity of the object's
internal state.

At 10:40 AM 12/21/2001 -0800, you wrote:
>Currently, there may be nothing that can go wrong with it.  But, putting a
>test
>in place will guarantee that if someone comes in and changes the
>implementation
>of the method and begins to return something other than what the system is
>expecting the test will break.
>:)
>
>-jason
>--- "STRAYER, JON (AIT)" <jon.strayer@...> wrote:
> > What could go wrong with this getter that is worth a test?
> >
> > >
> > > class A {
> > >     private int i;
> > >     getI(){
> > >         return i;
> > >     }
> > > }
> > >
> > > I want test the geter,should i make testcase as a inner class?
> >
>
>
>=====
>-----------------------------------------
>              Keep it simple...
>(1 Corinthians 2:2, Galatians 2:20, 6:14)
>
